reviews.review_text: Could not get into the book. Far too many academic references to obscure French writers and their works. Unless you have graduate degree in French literature you will not understand this book.
Patrick Modiano is one of my all-time favorite authors.  I liked these stories but really, they simply are not up to the superb quality of his later books.

After a few evenings of reading this stream-of-consciousness piece of crap, I understood the meaning of Warhol's statement, "Art is what you can get away with.  Very seldom do I desecrate this book, but after 2/3ds of the way through La Place d'Etoile," , I threw it into my front yard.  My dogs made short work of it.  What a fraudulent piece of work, and totally self-indulgent.
I found it tiresome to read at times, too much all at once. Maybe the journalistic style annoyed me when I was expecting a straightforward prose. It needs to be read slowly.

Absolutely unreadable. Wouldn't even give it one star. Forced myself to finish the first book and gave up halfway the second book. The only good thing about the first book: the second book is worse. The rambling went on and on. Unstoppable. Pages full of name lists, none of which makes sense. I rather spend my time reading my own shopping list.
This book centers on just after the Reich's loss. I've not read many books from this angle.

summary:
The Occupation Trilogy: La Place de l'Étoile - The Night Watch - Ring Roads

When Patrick Modiano was awarded the 2014 Nobel Prize for Literature, he was praised for using the "art of memory" to bring to life the Occupation of Paris during the Second World War. Born just after the war, Modiano was an angry young man in his twenties when he wrote these three brilliant, angry novels, bursting onto the Parisian literary scene and causing a storm.

The epigraph to his ambitious first novel, among the first to seriously question both wartime collaboration in France and the myths of the Gaullist era, reads: "In June 1942 a German officer goes up to a young man and says: 'Excuse me, monsieur, where is La Place de l'Étoile?' The young man points to the star on his chest." The Night Watch tells the story of a young man caught between his work for the French Gestapo, his work for a Resistance cell informing on the police, and the black market dealers whose seedy milieu he shares. Ring Roads recounts Serge's search for his father, who disappeared from his life ten years earlier. He finds him trying to survive the war years in the unlikely company of petty criminals, anti-Semites, and prostitutes, putting his meager business skills to the service of those who have no interest in him or his survival. 

Together, these three brilliant, almost hallucinatory evocations of the Occupation, attempt to exorcise the past by exploring the morally ambiguous worlds of collaboration and resistance. Award-winning translator Frank Wynne has revised the translations of The Night Watch and Ring Roads -- long out of print -- for our current day, and brings La Place de l'Etoile into English for the first time. The Occupation Trilogy provides the perfect introduction to one of the world's greatest writers.
